DataElement.preferredDefinition: Numeric result that reflects the result of a person's breast cancer risk assessment using the Claus Model, evaluating family history, laterality of the disease, incidence of other types of cancer, and BRCA1/2 status.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Evaluation of a person's risk of breast cancer using the Claus Model, evaluating family history, laterality of the disease, incidence of other types of cancer, and BRCA1/2 status.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: The Claus model predicts the probability of a woman's risk for developing breast cancer based on her family history. It focuses solely on family history to estimate the probability that a woman will develop breast cancer. Using this model requires providing information about first-degree and second-degree relatives who have had breast cancer. It factors in the ages at which these relatives were diagnosed. It can also include breast cancer history on the father's side of the family as well. It's main advantage is its expanded inclusion of family history information. It is limited in that it can be used only with women who have at least one first- or second-degree relative with breast cancer. Also, it does not take into account other risk factors such as the presence of atypical hyperplasia, age of first menstrual period, or age of first live birth.:A breast neoplasm with metastatic potential arising from the breast parenchyma or the nipple.  The most common are breast carcinomas.  Malignant breast neoplasms occur more frequently in females than in males. -- 2003

Concepts.definition: The Claus model predicts the probability of a woman's risk for developing breast cancer based on her family history. It focuses solely on family history to estimate the probability that a woman will develop breast cancer. Using this model requires providing information about first-degree and second-degree relatives who have had breast cancer. It factors in the ages at which these relatives were diagnosed. It can also include breast cancer history on the father's side of the family as well. It's main advantage is its expanded inclusion of family history information. It is limited in that it can be used only with women who have at least one first- or second-degree relative with breast cancer. Also, it does not take into account other risk factors such as the presence of atypical hyperplasia, age of first menstrual period, or age of first live birth.

A primary or metastatic malignant neoplasm involving the breast.  The vast majority of cases are carcinomas arising from the breast parenchyma or the nipple.  Malignant breast neoplasms occur more frequently in females than in males.

Property.preferredDefinition: The qualitative or quantitative estimation of the likelihood of adverse effects that may result from exposure to specified health hazards or from the absence of beneficial influences.

Concepts.definition: An estimated probability that one or more adverse event(s) will occur as a result of exposure to an actual or potential hazardous situation or chemical.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the results of evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Numeric result that reflects the result of a person's risk assessment evaluation.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the results of evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Outcome; a phenomenon that follows and is caused by some previous phenomenon.

DataElement.changeDescription: Released status approved by CCR on 6/10/2005.
